name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The Arts

transcript.content: Pablo Picasso once stated: "We all know that art is not truth. Art is a lie that makes us realize truth." From painting and poetry, symphonies and sculpture the arts bring beauty and illumination to some, confusion and frustration to others. But what is art? The idea of a work of art, created by an artist did not truly exist before the Renaissance. And what value do the art still have? Do they still make us realize the truth, or are they increasingly rarified and obsolete in this digital and disposable age?
With me to discuss the wide spectrum of the arts, are Steven Merchant, graduate of the University of Warwick and award winning writer.
Thank you so much for having me.
Ricky increasingly annoyed
And Karl Pilkington, a man with no qualifications, very little education, but who's now known on the world over, as a man with a head like a fucking ORANGE! Cuuuunt
Alright?
Well I suppose if I could pick up on something from your introduction, Ricky. You posed the question, in a sense what is art? It's a very broad term.

It's a very difficult one as well. I think the earliest people to ponder it were the Greeks. And I think they thought that art was, and it's point was to try and emulate as close as possible the beauty of nature.
So they knew art was a quest for beauty and I suppose they thought nature was pretty perfect in its aesthetic. And so the point of an artist was to tap into that.
Well, let me throw that question over to Karl Pilkington.
What do you want to know?
Well, we were just trying to clarify what art is. Ricky was just referring back to the Greeks.

It's just something for your eyes to look at. It's just a change from the norm, innit? I mean that's why I think most people have it, but then the problem is I'd never buy a piece of art. I don't see the point in buying something, because I know my eyes would get bored of it eventually.
Right

So it's better to keep it in a museum like a lot of places, lot of museums keep the stuff, they rotate it. Because people get sick of looking at it. They shift the art around don't they? People go "I'm sick of that now" they move it around the world, let someone else's eyes look at it.'
Well, that's more to get everyone the chance to see it, as opposed to people who looked at it once and now they're sick of it.
Oh, not the shitting Mona Lisa again! If I have to stare at that little bitch...
How many times can you look at the same thing? I think there's a snobbery with art. I think people do go "oh, have you seen the new thing at the Louvre?" "Oh yeah, it's lovely"
I think there should be a snobbery with art.
Why?

Because the world is full of idiots and there's not a safety in numbers with art. I think you should be a complete fascist when you're creating a work of art. I don't think it's open to utilitarian or democratic referendum.
You end up With the X-Factor winner that way.
No I know, but that pleases the masses, that's what I'm saying. There was a painting knocking about when I was a kid, called the "Blue Boy". Now every house had one, right.

It turned out, it was just a bloke who had a load and he was just flogging them to everyone. But the thing is, that sums up art to me. Someone's got a load, "D'ya want one?" "Go on then, I got a wall to fill" and they stick it on. It's not "now, what does that represent?" "what's that going to bring to the room?"
It's just filling a gap. And that's what art is to me, just filling a gap that otherwise would have naught in it.
But you're obsessed with the functionality of things. This is all you're ever obsessed with, "what's its function?". Things always need to get you from A to Z in some way. And art is not about that.
Have you got much art in you're house?
Yes.
Really?
Beacuse it gives me pleasure, and I don't get bored of it.
Do you look at it every day?
Well... it's there isn't it? It just adds...
Yeah, but other things are there. Dust is there but...
Surprisingly I have not compared art to dust as often as I perhaps should.
Ricky giggles

But the thing about... And this is I think may be intriguing to you: Damien Hirst of course, is more of a conceptual artist like Tracy Emin, and a lot of what contemporary art does is followed on from a guy called Marcell Duchamp, who I'm sure you're familiar whit.
Karl moans 'alright'
Ricky and Steve snigger
Now he famously took a gentleman's white urinal, like you would find in a pub toiled, and he put it on its side and he signed it with a fake name and he put it in an art gallery.
Now he did that in about 1917, perhaps a bit later.
It just annoys me. Because there'll be snobby people who haven't got a clue. And they're looking at that and go "oh yeah, I see what he's trying to say."
But that may make them think
Damien Hirst, I don't feel angry with Damien Hirst really, because he's getting away with it.
But why does that annoy you?
Because it's people falling into the trap. Damien Hirst before he dies, I bet he goes "What a laugh that was, I had everyone on"
There's a very good point as well, because some people think that the greatest art form of the last 100 years is marketing.
Yeah

Some people say that is his art. That it's not good enough to do it, you gotta then get away with it. And if the point of art is to inflame, I don't think anything inflames people more than the discussion about whether something's art or someone's taking the piss. Or if someone gets 50 million for something, do they deserve it, is it worth a hospital?
Well what do you think? What do you think of the shark in a tank?
I think I was blown away by it. I thought I never seen anything like it before.
It was sort of spectacular, because it's so huge and so vast. And to have put a shark in you know, in formaldehyde and to have hung it in an art gallery is very striking when you see it.
Well it is!
But what is he? Is he an artist or a fishmonger?!
Ricky bursts laughing
What he's done.. Anyone could have done what he did
Yes, but not everyone did it, he did it.

This is an interesting point that you raise. It's the same old point that you always raise: Anyone could have done it. That's always the same point you make, that anyone could have done it. But they didn't do it!
But Karl! You could say the same about Michelangelo. Is he an artist or a painter & decorator?

Well, it hasn't caught on has it, like the Crying Boy photograph. No one's having them in their house, no one's going "oh have you seen this, have you seen the new trend, a shark in a tank.." No one's got the room, no one wants it!
And that to me, shows what's popular. At the end of the day, if everyone wants one it's gotta be good innit?

But I think if people would give a chance to appreciate more sophisticated things then they would. And I just think that's true in all walks in life. It's an aquired taste. And the best things are an aquired taste. They really are
If all you eat is processed cheese and white bread, you get a taste for it. But if you try something that's, you know in my opinion better than that, then you'll leave that behind.
That's pretty rich, coming from you!
I know, I love a bit of cheddar don't I? I'm my mother's pride.
Whereas if you were to be offered perhaps some calamary, your reaction would be?
Squid. Get it out of my face!
Sure. But I take your point Rick, thanks anyway.
Ricky laughs
Calamary wasn't an artist by the way.
I haven't got pictures in our flat, cause of that mirrored wall I've got, right? I mean it's tiny, he's been in it.
I've got windows on one wall, door to get in on the other, kitchen on the other, mirrored wall on the other.
So there's no space for art.
There's no space for art.
I'm intrigued how you sit at home... Where's the sofa?
At home? Facing the mirror.
So sit looking at yourself all night
Yeah
As opposed to a painting
Yeah, but at least that changes each day.
No it doesn't.
It does, the picture changes.
No it's not, it's round and miserable. Every fucking day.
No no, honestly. It's good to... because you don't look at yourself otherwise. Especially me, I haven't got any hair to comb or anything.
So I don't look in the mirror as much as the normal person. Whereas now, I'm looking there every day.
So you're sat at home staring at yourself?
No because the telly is in front of the mirror.
But are you not distracted by yourself?
Yeah you do, when the adverts are on you look up. And if Suzanne's sat next to me, I tend to talk to her through the mirror.
Ricky bursts laughing
What d'ya mean? So why don't you look at her while you talk to her?
You don't have to turn your neck or anything.
There's no neck usage going on. I can just look forward. I look at the telly, lift the eyes up, look in the mirror, look at me, look at her.
(laughing) What does she do?
Look back to you in the mirror?
No, we're used to it. There's nothing wrong with that. It's like there's more people in the room in a way
And they're further away!
There's nothing odd about that. Why wouldn't you use...
Sorry, why wouldn't you talk to your girlfriend via a mirror all the time?! Is that your question?
No, I think it's quite normal.
If your head is facing a mirror where you can see everything in that room, you know it's a small flat, I can see everything that's going on in there without movin' me head.
Stephen Hawking would be well happy.
Ricky laughs
But I can look forward, she's sat next to me. If I'm watching the telly I can say something, now she's getting the sound from me still because she's sat close.
Yeah
But yeah, we're further away but things look better from a distance anyway.
So that's how you managed to keep this relationship alive?
Maybe
(laughing) You are just such an odd little man!
But no, it's not odd.
You see there was a woman on the estate who did use...
Have I tell you about Ms. Piggy before?
No
It rings a bell...
Go on
I think I told you ages ago, it's this fat woman who used to be on the estate, she had a three-wheeler bike
Ricky sniggers
What, a push-bike, pedal bike?
Yeah, like a tricycle thing, but a big one
She used to sit her husband in the basket in the back, cycle about and what have you
Yeah
Oh, is this the one that she used to beat him up, so your dad pretended to be a policeman?
Yeah, that's it.
That's the one, you remember?
No I don't remember this.
Yeah, she used to always duff her husband up and that and people in the area knew that she's being a bit tight on him, and me dad went round with his mate and sort of...
But what's this got to do with the mirror?
Anyway, the way she used to communicate...

She used to always go to Kwik Save to nick biscuits. And if anyone went up to her to say stop nicking the biscuits, she'd pull out like a little mirror out of her bag and she'd look in it, but talk to you via the mirror.
Ricky laughs
Oh god! Oh man. This place you grew up...
So she's insane
It's weird isn't it
It was really weird, it used to scare me
It's like Narnia
It's like a Salvador Dali painting. You exist in there
Yeah. It's really really weird
So hang on, she used to talk to people via the mirror, because she was mental
I couldn't sit watch the telly and look at me watching the telly all night
No
That's weird
That would be really weird.
But why?
It's really weird Karl!
I'd be very conscious of myself.
No I think it gives you confidence and that
Gives you confidence?
Well yeah, because you're seeing yourself more and you pick up what habits you do and stuff like that
So what have you changed through your view of yourself
I sort of grew a beard through the week, just something different to look at for a bit.
And then you get sick of that, it's like a piece of art, change that, have a bit of a shave.
Can you see the back of the telly in the mirror?
A little bit, yeah
If the flat's a mess, it's a mess twice.
Ricky bursts laughing
Oh god

The earliest art that we know, which we call cave paintings, they date back between 30,000 and 10,000 years B.C. Even those people tried to brighten up their cave with a bit of art. So in many ways they were more advanced than you.
Yeah but they didn't have a big mirror.
I mean, if you're living in a cave, let's face it, you're not going to go mad if your kids start drawing, doodling on the cave wall are ya?
Doesn't matter
Right
Brighten it up
But they always did the same thing. It was always a Yak, wannit?
What?
Yeah, but they drew what they saw, I mean yeah. I love the fact that 30,000 years ago they're being criticized for being a bit literal.
No, but surely if all you ever see when you step out of the cave is a Yak, do something different for the wall when you get in.
(laughing) What?
Why is it always a Yak on every wall?
Is it always a Yak?
It's always a Yak. Whenever you see these Tom Robinson Time Team programs
Who's Tom Robinson?
He's the guy who did Motorway, didn't he?
Yeah and they had a seventies singer songwriter. Tony Robinson, you mean.
Tony Robinson. Whenever you see him digging around...
"Hold up everyone! Get the brush, what's this, what's this?"
It's always a Yak! Yet they pretend they're interested.
So you're saying that you wouldn't draw a Yak, you just saw one outside?
This what I'm saying to you about trends. One person has it, the next caveman will go "Oh, I'll have one of them on my wall, yeah I'll do a Yak."
Why was there no one doing something a bit different?
Well, it's not true! They did. This thing about being a Yak...
It's just in your own head.
The programs I've seen... I've been to Pompeii, where they had doodling on the walls. And that was all like knobs, tits and arse all over the shop.
Yeah
Now, do that now and people go "that's a disgrace, rub that out! Clean that! Get it down!"
Whereas now, if you see one in Pompeii they go "oh wow, look at that, look at the detail on that"
Well yeah
And that's what I'm saying, there's a snobbery in art. It's the same knob. The knob has not changed.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Yeah, but I imagine in 50,000 years time if they dig up you know, a cubicle and there's tits and arse, people will take pictures of it again.
They won't be, this is the interesting thing with the way we live now. We're cleaning stuff up constantly now. There's no, almost no record of our time.
Cause we're getting rid of everything. We clean everything up. Everything's clean. Getting rid of rubbish, recycling everything.
Well, that's a very good point. Is graffiti a valid art form?
Some of it is.
I think it is, yeah. I mean we're not talking about the classic spunk & dick, which is still, I mean it's still great, isn't it?
Well, I mean if I
If you see a lovely clean white wall and you see a spunk & dick on it, you're gonna laugh
Always laugh.
Do you add hair to the testicles when you're drawing the spunk & dick?
A few.
Cause mine are always clean, the testicles are always clean.
Really?
I put on a 4-5 bristles sticking out, straight.
See, I always thought that was a kind of commoner version of it.
It looks like, mine looks like
I don't mean my real one, I mean my...
You're illustrative
Yeah yeah yeah
It looks like two gooseberries and Thunderbird II.
Do you add much detail at the tip of the penis?
No. It's a straightforward, dissection across, just a line across to show the helmet. One little line for the eye.
And do you tend to keep the same number of droplets coming out? Spunk droplets
I do three, but I don't do the line, I actually do the little teardrop droplets
The teardrop droplets of spunk, yeah
And that is the spunk & dick, as I see it.
When I was at school it was referred to - and maybe this is specific to Bristol - it was referred to as The Sacred.
Why?
"I've just drawn a Sacred"
Oh really?
I don't know what the origin of that was.
Some graffiti is funny
I saw one in London, it just said "Rachel is a big arsed, big chinned cunt"
Now, I think Rachel is gonna see that and know that I'm the only big arsed, big chinned cunt round here. I don't know how big her chin was
Sure
I think her chin might be looking like the arse
Yeah yeah yeah
Maybe she couldn't see the last part of it, because  chin was in the way. "Rachel is a b..." and that's all she could see
Now where was this graffiti written?
It was near Center Point
So you think someone was so angry with Rachel?
Well I think maybe Rachel nicked this woman's fella?
Right
And she went out and
Scrawled that, in a lot of different places
Yeah
I saw one that was, back in Bristol, it was something like "Michael Peters is gay"
And I always wondered if that was Michael Peters himself, who was having trouble coming out of the closet
Yeah
And he was just writing that in a lot of different places, so by the time he finally mentioned people were "yeah I knew that anyway, I saw it in a toilet"
Sculptures. What do you think of sculptures?
I mean that's something, that's really getting into the 3D world there. No longer you have to represent something as 3D, you can make something. You know, statues are amazing, aren't they?
They're clever, aren't they? I mean they always look the same.
Well, that's not true, is it? Because recently there was a quite controversial one, a huge one. In London, the pregnant thalidomide woman. What do you think of that?
Oh yeah, I saw that.
Thoughts?
I wouldn't have it in my house.
Wheezing laugh from Ricky
Well, there wouldn't be room, because it would be just you, Suzanne, and a pregnant thalidomide watching telly.
I don't know what it was trying to say.
Maybe she was saying ok, we've had the human form. This is an example of the human form.
Yeah, but do you think she started off trying to do normal, and then she was like "Oh, I chipped a bit off!'
Ricky explodes with laughter
One of the arms got chipped off?
Well, it makes you wonder, don't it?

And why... You see that square, Trafalgar Square, you got that. Nelson's Column, he's got one arm, and a leg missing or something and a patch over his eye. Then you've got the thalidomide... Why can't they just do a full person?
(laughing) Well, that was what they saw, that's what the artist saw.

It's about confronting us with certain preconceptions of what we expect of the human form. What we expect of sculpture. It's probably a little ironic comment as well on the famous Rodin. It's wrapped up with all kinds of ideas of maternity of the human form, of what sculpture is. Why wouldn't you put that in a big public place?
What about the subject? Did you think who is that subject? Who is that woman?
No, not really, because thalidomides are around, we've all seen one. It's not like a shocking image. It's one of life's little things that it chucks out. There's some out there
Amazing
It's not shocking, is it? I don't understand what you mean? I think what I thought is it just goes to show that we're running out of ideas.
What do you think of people who are so angry at art, that they try to censor it or they try and destroy it? Do you think art should ever be censored?
It's where you put it. If it's in a gallery, then it doesn't have to be censored. If it's in Trafalgar Square, where everyone wandering around having a nice time
You don't want a twelve foot cock.
Ricky laughs

So it's all about where you put it. I think some art looks better because of where it is. Angel of the North, that's a bit of art, but it's a bit of a surprise innit? You drive along a miserable motorway. "Oh what's that over there?" It gives something for your eyes to look at again. Motorways are the most boring places to drive, but you go "oh there's a bit of art over there"
Yeah, but then again, should you be looking at art when you're going at 70mph along a motorway?
Well yeah, because it's really big, you can keep you're eye on it
Look in the mirror
It's not a problem
When you go past it, look in the mirror like normal
So you like the Angel of the North
Because it's something in the middle of nothing
Right, but if you put it somewhere else?
Stick it in Trafalgar Square, you'd go "Ah, more clutter!"

Now you've spoken Karl, about art and how it happens bla bla bla, and Ricky just pointed out that in some instances art has been considered very controversial, very provocative and has been banned. Famously one thinks of the Nazis, banning and burning certain books. Not all of which was just books criticizing them it was often artistic works, which they felt were subversive in some sense. And you get that in many oppressive regimes where people's artistic work is not allowed to express the way they feel about something - Stalinist Russia for instance, art there literature - not able to express their views, because people see it as dangerous, as provocative.
Well yeah, the threat always comes from scholars. With like any dictatorship, and they know that.

But not just scholars writing scholarly text, criticisms, but also people expressing their views through poetry, through creativity, things which are not direct. They can be abstract yet they can still be subversive.

Yeah but I think if it's done in a way that isn't just like a lunatic, they get away with it. Like a nice poem, some people will see it in a different light. I might read it and go "I don't even know what they're going on about there". So as long it's done clever, get away with it, don't they?
But that's often not the case
That's what I'm saying, that often in these regimes these things are repressed.
No, there's always like code words they can use and they can't have you on it
Such as?
I don't know, I'm not into that sort of work.
So you just made a statement that's not backed up with any actual information?

No, he made a point there, there was a very good point there. The McCarthy era. Where he was threatened by Communism, infiltrating the country and he thought that entertainers might be a part of that, the conspiracy. It was a hotbed and he made everyone come forward, writers, actors saying they're not a communist, and some people were out in the cold. So people had to be a bit clever, like it was Arthur Miller the Crucible. It's a metaphor, it's about witch hunts but it's about McCarthyism.
So yes, good point, you can put coded messages into art.
CB radio was the same thing
Go on
Well, there's all the codes
Hmmm, ok I thought you had a... I mean I was trying to make your point more valid than it obviously was.
No but if you need to refer to CB radio, that's the obvious...
No, just the one that I can relate to.
Yeah, we've done this, there's no point in CB radio. They go "How many candles are you burnin'?" "What?" "How old are you?" "Eight." "Ok, yeah."
I mean there's no point to those codes at all.
This is in no way relatable to the Crucible. Why would you be talking about one of the most respected plays in the 20th Century and suddenly in you're head, this reminds you of CB radio.
Just having this code going on that only certain people know how to break.
Everyone. Everyone knew it.
Ricky sniffs
Pointless
No, not back then they didn't.
Pointless

I remember we were shown the cartoon version of Animal Farm when we were about like 15-16, we were discussing about it afterwards "Oh yeah communism vs the poor proletariat" and all this, and this bloke went "You lot make me sick! It was a nice film about some animals."
Steve laughs
Brilliant
What's your take on that Karl?
Never seen it
No, go on, go on. What's your point? Because you can see the irony there, don't you?
I haven't seen it
If you want to do a serious point, don't use animals.

No? Well, I disagree with you there because we're going to get into literature later and I think my favorite is probably Charles Dickens and I think the greatest story ever told is A Christmas Carol. And there's only one way that could be improved, and that is a Muppet Christmas Carol.
That's absolutely right, yeah.
And I think people could take a lesson from that, and do other films with the Muppets. A Muppet Schindler's List.
Yeah
I mean, you could make it so moving, couldn't you?
Schindler's List in Space!
Ricky laughing
Yeah, yeah. Well, I think it would certainly help bring that story to a wider audience.
I think so, yeah
Like Karl, who are put off perhaps by the depressing black & white, they would suddenly see the Muppets singing and dancing
Ms. Piggy's Choice
Ms. Piggy's Choice, yeah
Have we talked about that?
What?
About things like that in art as well. Bringing something so serious to the masses, like films do, like the Holocaust. And like Sophie's Choice, where she has to chose which child lives and dies.
Why did she have to pick?
Well, because the Nazis were horrible, nasty, evil people.
Which one did she pick?
I don't think that's the point. I don't think that's the point.
This is not a betting game!
No but I imagine this is like Deal or No Deal. It's kind of down to the last two. Which one are you going to go for?
Silent laugh from Ricky
Oh god...
But why did you ask which one did she chose? Because even if he did say the names - Robert and Alison - what difference would it make? You don't know the story.
No because I'd ask more, I'd ask more then. If you said Alison, I'd go "what was it with Alison, what did she have over Robert?"
That's what films are meant to do, you question it. Whenever I watch a film with Suzanne, I always say at the end "What was going on there?"
Ah Jesus Christ!
That's because you're an idiot!
That's because you just watched the Muppet Christmas Carol and you can't understand how's a frog able to talk.
I'm all for films with a good storyline.
Yeah?
Brilliant. That's a perfect point! One extraordinary point.
He's gonna follow this up mate. His gonna follow this up.
He's got something here, he's got something here.
Karl, go on then, what's your take on films?
Films are really good, you can get lost in them.
Right
You like one with a good story
I mean whenever anyone asks, it's always the same.
It's Elephant Man. Kes. Mission Impossible II.
Steve & Ricky laugh

transcript.actor: ricky & steve at the same time
transcript.content: Mission Impossible II?
These are what you consider great works of film art?
No, I'm just saying these are the ones I've enjoyed recently.
There's so many films that I haven't seen and you always say "Oh have you seen so and so"
Well, Mission Impossible I.
Ricky laughs
And good news for you! III is out!
That's true.

One of the most striking art exhibitions I've ever attended Karl, was an exhibition of outsider art, of which I'm sure you're very familiar with. Outsider art of course is work that is made by people who are often institutionalized, for mental health problems, or they are just incredibly... People who aren't in any way part of the art establishment.

Right up to psychopathic mass murderers. Clinically insane mass murderers would count as outsider art. I went to an outsider art exhibition in New York, it was incredible and I bought a painting of this guy, he's a chronic schizophrenic, and he paints in tar. Like road tar that he gets from roads and he paints on woods he finds in sort of skips and it's incredible because it's like scratched in. And it's amazing. There's this thing of Jesus being helped down off the cross. And you have to study it but it's there and it's quite incredible that it's just scratched in the wood by tar.

And there's loads of things like that. I was walking around, admittedly I was walking around like going "this is fucking mental!" and Jane was going "you've got to stop saying that!" Cause of course some of the people are mental.
One of the sculptures was a skull, right (laughs)
And underneath like a little head with teeth. Underneath he put a sign that said "REAL TEETH"
Ricky & Steve both laugh
(laughing) Where did he get the real teeth from?

What I think is interesting about that is, how much therapy it provides for these often mentally unstable people. Which is an other important value of art of course. People self express, being able to give a little piece of themselves through their work. Do you not see any value in that?
How do you express yourself?
Whistle
Ricky laughs in pain
You whistle?
Yeah I found over Christmas, I whistle a lot more than I usually do. And I think that was just freedom.
What do you mean freedom?
Right, expand on this point if you would.
Well that's art is, innit? It's you being free from all the world's heaviness.
See, that's a great quote, that. That's great, that. For art is freedom, I love that because I think you really hit it on something there.
Would you include the "free of all the world's heaviness" on that quote?
Well, I know what he meant there. I mean I would include the world's heaviness in my freedom. You know some artist are attracted to the dark side, the heaviness of the world.
But I just want to return to you whistling as your artistic expression of freedom. Why do you find yourself whistling more?
That's what was weird.
So just take us through a typical day, when would the whistling begin?
Sorry, this was that you spent your Christmas down in Kent with Suzanne and her parents
Yeah
Could I suggest something? Your freedom was thinking, "I'm in my own place now, I'm gonna annoy them"
Well it was mainly when we were playing Scrabble. And they were taking ages to have their go, and couldn't have the radio on because the boiler affects the radio.
It works, it just gives something off. Every time the boiler kicks in the radio goes all staticky.
Right
So I was just sort of supplying the soundtrack.
Ricky laughs

synopsis.description: The story of the Blue Boy painting
